title: Syria war: Turkey offensive sparks fear of humanitarian crisis
text:
At least 100,000 people have fled their homes after Turkey invaded Syria (Picture: Getty)

At least 100,000 people have fled their homes in Syria amid the Turkish invasion – sparking fears of a potential humanitarian crisis.

Thousands of people including children are now living in makeshift camps after Turkey launched the military action on Wednesday.

Turkey has sent in ground and air troops to clear its border of the Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF).

While the SDF is a key US ally that defeated the Islamic State in Syria, Turkey regards the Kurdish militants as terrorists for their links to anti-Turkish insurgents.

Turkey invaded just days after US President Donald Trump announced he would be pulling back troops from the Turkey-Syria border.

At least 11 civillians including a baby have died in the offensive which has been condemned by the United Nations.

The UN has estimated the number of displaced at 100,000 saying that markets, schools and clinics have been closed.

Aid agencies have warned of a humanitarian crisis, with nearly a half-million people at risk in northeastern Syria.

Many people are sheltering in schools or other buildings in Hassakeh city and the town of Tal Tamer, according to the UN.

The UN’s World Food Programme (WFP) said that 70,000 people have been forced to flee the provinces of al-Hassakeh and al-Raqqa due to the Turkish onslaught.

Children hold a Turkish flag as they give their support to the military during the deployment of tanks in Akcakale, Turkey (Picture: Getty) Pro-Turkish Syrian fighters cross the border into Syria as they take part in an offensive against Kurdish-controlled areas (Picture: Getty)

Turkey-backed Syrian rebel fighters walk together in the border town of Akcakale in Sanliurfa province (Picture: Reuters)

An explosives-laden vehicle detonated on Friday in a busy neighbourhood of Qamishli, one of the main Kurdish cities in northeastern Syria (Picture: AFP)

According to Unicef, most people have been fleeing from the city of Ras al-Ain and the town of Tal Abiad, where Turkey has focused its military efforts.

It is reported a camp of 4,000 displaced residents about seven miles from the frontier was evacuated after artillery shells landed nearby.

Turkey had slammed the warning of an impending humanitarian crisis as ‘fabricated in order to discredit its counter-terrorism efforts.’

Despite criticism from world leaders, Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan vowed ‘we will not stop no matter what anyone says’.

Unicef reports that a safe water pump in Ras al-Ain for at least 400,000 people was out of service after being attacked, while two schools in Tal Abiad were taken over for military use.

People walk in Akcakale, Sanliurfa province, southeastern Turkey, as Turkish forces artillery pieces fire targets towards Syria (Picture: AP)

The aid agency has hundreds of staff providing help to refugees in displacement camps.

A spokesperson for Unicef said: ‘An escalation of hostilities in the area is likely to have serious consequences on the ability of humanitarian actors to provide protection and assistance to thousands of vulnerable children.

‘Unicef reiterates that the only solution to the brutal conflict in Syria is a political solution.

‘The protection of children in the northeast of Syria and across the country must be prioritised at all times.’
